0.32.text:
BBC Three have recently announced their decision
not to renew the BAFTA award winning zombie

4.71.text:
show In The Flesh, much to the disappointment
and upset of so many fans. Myself included.

10.17.text:
Hello.
Here's BBC Three's official statement:

12.99.text:
"BBC Three is very proud of the two award
winning series of In The Flesh, however, given

17.67.text:
there is only budget for one original drama
series a year on the channel it won't be returning.

22.32.text:
We love the show but have to make hard choices
to bring new shows through and create room

25.78.text:
for emerging talent. Huge thanks to the BAFTA
award winning writer Dominic Mitchell and

30.49.text:
the superb cast."
Isn't that just lovely? Well, no. Not really.

34.52.text:
I'm not going to be rude about BBC Three because
they have aired two series of this amazing

40.23.text:
show and they're a pretty cool channel but
I do think they are making an absolutely massive

45.66.text:
mistake by axing this show. This is possibly
the most appalling decision anyone has ever

50.84.text:
made at any point in their life ever in human
history.

53.66.text:
In the words of Kieren Walker: "I'm sorry,
but that is bullshit!"

57.78.text:
Did you like my impression? I didn't like
my impression either it was terrible.

61.48.text:
For those of you that don't know what In The
Flesh is I wrote a little summary which I'm

64.60.text:
going to read to you now.
Kieren Walker, an 18 year old Northern lad

68.21.text:
kills himself after his best friend, (or maybe
more) dies while on a tour of duty in Afghanistan.

73.45.text:
In 2009 Kieren comes back from the dead along
with everyone else who died in that year in

79.71.text:
In his zombie-like, untreated state, he kills
people and eats their brains.

83.66.text:
After a period of war in which the Human Volunteer
Force are set up to fight the zombie threat,

87.92.text:
said remaining zombies are captured, treated,
and then integrated back into society.

91.85.text:
As a PDS Sufferer, that’s a Partially Deceased
Syndrome Sufferer, Kieren must somehow restart

97.46.text:
his life where he left off. This is difficult
beause as a PDS sufferer he is now a second

101.79.text:
class citizen who faces oppression, segregation,
abuse, a huge media compaign determined to

107.08.text:
demonise him and his kind and a massive lack
of understanding about his condition.

110.59.text:
If that is not the recipe for a killer show
then I don’t know what is.

114.08.text:
I also made a list this morning of many of
the themes explored in In The Flesh. So we

118.44.text:
have: mental illness, oppression, abuse, PTSD,
the impact of war, abuse of power and corrupt

125.49.text:
authority figures, the pros and cons of religion,
extremism, terminal illness, LGBT issues such

131.44.text:
as heteronormativity and casual homophobia,
the fetishisation of minorities, families,

136.95.text:
patriarchy, the pressure on young men to live
up to patriarchal ideals, loss and the different

141.38.text:
ways people deal with it, identity, death,
activism, segregation, propaganda, and media

147.27.text:
influence. And that's just off the top of
my head this morning there are so many more

150.64.text:
issues than that dealt with in the show.
So as you can probably tell this show is pretty

154.80.text:
damn special.
The reason so many of us are upset about this,

157.78.text:
aside from the fact that In The Flesh is the
most beautiful, intelligent, groundbreaking,

161.79.text:
subtle, real show you will ever see is that
Kieren Walker is LGBT. Kieren Walker is the

169.37.text:
hero of our show, he's 18 years old, he is
bisexual or pansexual or maybe even demisexual

174.57.text:
but he definitely falls on the spectrum. He
is our unquestioned hero. He is mentally ill.

180.02.text:
He suffers from anxiety and he also tried
to kill himself and oddly enough in this instance

184.36.text:
actually achieved that. Okay so you might
be thinking why is this relevant? It is relevant

189.29.text:
because straight people can get hundreds and
thousands of shows where there are straight

194.31.text:
protagonists and straight leads and straight
romance and nobody bats an eyelid. I mean,

199.18.text:
let's be honest, shows with straight protagonists
can be embarrassingly, painfully awful and

203.67.text:
they'll just keep getting recommissioned season
after season after season after season. I

208.10.text:
was going to mention show that's recently
got renewed but you know what, I'm not that

211.82.text:
mean and it's not about that so I'm not gonna
go there.

214.35.text:
Straight people only have to turn on the television
to pretty much any channel and they will see

217.90.text:
themselves represented, they will see themselves
as heroes, they will see themselves as villains,

221.84.text:
they will see those people who are neither
heroes or villains, they will see themselves

225.26.text:
as three dimensional human beings and their
sexuality won't be made into this major facet

230.21.text:
of their character that's stereotyped and
made fun of all the time.

233.09.text:
The thing is, we don't have that luxury. Seriously,
when was the last time you watched a British

236.87.text:
drama with a bisexual lead character? When
was that? When was the last time you actually

241.41.text:
saw a bisexual character anywhere on tv that
wasn't stereotyped as being greedy or manipulative

247.15.text:
or disloyal or confused. I don't see those
characters anywhere and I'm bisexual and I

252.37.text:
look for them everywhere.
Chances are you'll think on that question

255.44.text:
and you'll realise you have either never seen
that sort of lead or you've very rarely seen

260.07.text:
that sort of lead, but either way we need
more of them.

262.70.text:
How often do they think we get something like
this? This show is absolutely groundbreaking.

267.58.text:
We can't just go, oh my favourite show's been
axed. Oh well, I'll go and turn onto another

272.56.text:
channel and I'll find another character that
I can deeply relate to. I'm not saying that

277.77.text:
LGBT people can't relate to straight people,
we can and we do all the time, but it's also

282.12.text:
nice to see someone who shares your struggles
and your pain and to be able to relate to

285.85.text:
them on that deep human level.
Also most of the LGBT characters on tv at

289.84.text:
the moment are either stereotyped or they're
the sidekick or they're played for laughs

293.48.text:
and I just don't enjoy watching that.
Basically what I'm trying to say is that we

296.46.text:
can't just shift our allegiance to another
show because there is nothing like this out

300.43.text:
there.
What does it take for a show about us and

302.90.text:
people like us to be safe?
In The Flesh has won a BAFTA, Luke Newberry,

306.85.text:
the lead, who is amazing, was nominated for
best actor. It won the best tv show, the best

313.17.text:
2014 tv show on the Radio Times poll. It beat
BBC Sherlock, think about that, that's massive.

318.01.text:
It's has an absolutely massive fandom all
over the world. Recently we got In The Flesh

322.41.text:
trending worldwide, that's how big the fandom
is. It's got the most talented, kind, giving

328.31.text:
actors and they're so supportive to the fan
base and it also has the most beautiful, delicate

332.73.text:
writing I think you will ever experience.
So what's missing here? I'm really struggling

337.33.text:
to see why they would cancel this show.
The cast and the crew have expressed that

340.85.text:
they want to make a third series, so what's
the problem? Paraphrasing Kieren Walker again

345.47.text:
here, this show is a gift. It's a one time
thing and it's so important.

349.74.text:
This isn't an LGBT show. We don't have to
go and find it in the LGBT section. It's a

354.88.text:
zombie show. It's horror. It's drama. It's
about family and relationships. It's just

360.18.text:
a normal show in which LGBT people are allowed
to be themselves without being lazy stereotypes.

366.56.text:
Our main character Kieren is bisexual or pansexual
or demisexual but that is by no means the

371.54.text:
most important or interesting thing about
him. Going into the show that is an already

375.21.text:
established part of his character it's not
ignored, it's just there. Kieren's sexuality

380.26.text:
is written as a part of who he is, just another
aspect of his very interesting, complex character,

386.86.text:
and that is an incredibly healthy attitude
to have.

389.88.text:
It's refreshing to see a show that doesn't
cater to heteronormativity or patriarchy.

394.19.text:
It refuses to conform and like Kieren it refuses
to be bullied.

396.73.text:
Here we have a young bisexual male character
who is also mentally ill and really kind.

402.13.text:
He's our unquestioned hero but he's not violent
or cruel, he doesn't need to run about with

406.12.text:
a gun to prove that. He doesn't want to hurt
people, he just wants to do the right thing

409.55.text:
and I think that's incredibly relatable to
a lot of people. And not only is that relatable,

413.82.text:
it's a refusal to conform to society's current
prejudices. Think what this means for young

418.47.text:
boys watching. Kieren is unashamedly nice.
So often boys think that they have to be tough

424.12.text:
and aggressive and even violent to be the
hero, but Kieren proves that's not the case.

429.00.text:
We root for Kieren because he's ordinary and
we like him.

431.62.text:
Kieren gets anxiety, he's claustrophobic,
he suffered very badly from depression. He

436.29.text:
describes his first life as varying levels
of fear and that's something that's intensely

440.45.text:
relatable to other young mentally ill people.
He's an artist and in his bedroom there's

444.55.text:
a painting of himself in a cage which is the
most brilliant visual representation of what

449.39.text:
it feels like to be mentally ill.
Kieren was so troubled that he killed himself

452.77.text:
in his first life, so he's definitely either
mentally ill or has suffered from mental illness.

457.06.text:
Kieren's story is so real and raw. Do you
know how many LGBT mentally ill kids try to

461.78.text:
kill themselves? A lot. It happens tragically
often. You're currently listening to a mentally

466.35.text:
ill bisexual young woman who tried to kill
herself. I could have been like Kieren but

469.87.text:
luckily my attempt failed, thank God.
Kieren's story shows us that there's still

473.59.text:
hope and that life is worth living. Although
it doesn't imply that giving up is cowardly

477.21.text:
it clearly shows that it's not an answer either.
I don't know if we'll ever get a show like

481.26.text:
this again and that's really sad.
It does feel like a kick in the teeth to all

484.53.text:
of us lot that aren't usually represented
in the media. This was our one show, this

488.90.text:
was it. This was our escape from everything.
Watching In The Flesh we got to be the heroes,

493.17.text:
we got to be complex and three dimensional.
We had our issues dealt with sensitively and

498.15.text:
intelligently by a really fantastic writer
and an amazing cast.

501.21.text:
For that I can only thank Dominic Mitchell
who is an absolutely outstanding writer. Not

505.86.text:
only has he created something progressive
and unique but he's helped so many young people

510.64.text:
along the way.
We are still fighting to keep our show. BBC

513.70.text:
Three might want to throw it away but surely
there are other avenues we can pursue? There

517.17.text:
must be other channels and other networks
out there that might be interested.

520.51.text:
We've made the subject trend on twitter, we've
started petitions, we've made art, we've made

524.54.text:
blog entires, we've spread the word and we've
complained very politely to the BBC.

528.82.text:
We need them to listen and know how important
this show is. Even, dare I say it, lifesaving.

533.94.text:
The fandom is not giving up. We don't believe
it's over and we are in total denial right

538.75.text:
now. We are gonna fight for this show until
the bitter end. We are stubborn and passionate

543.52.text:
and we are the fandom that can make anything
happen. We are respectfully asking that this

547.68.text:
terrible decision is rethought because this
show means so much to so many people.

552.65.text:
You can help our campaign by signing the petitions
below. I'm going to put them in the description

556.46.text:
box. You can tweet about In The Flesh using,
I believe there are three hashtags being used

560.44.text:
at the moment. There is #saveintheflesh #inthefleshneedsahome
and #renewintheflesh. You can tweet Netflix,

567.17.text:
Amazon UK, BBC Two, BBC Three, BBC One, Channel
Four, any of them, all of them go for it!

574.07.text:
Be polite but be heard and if all this fails
then at least we'll know we've done our utmost

578.17.text:
to keep this gorgeous, moregeous show running.
At the very least this show needs a proper

583.55.text:
end.
Thank you so much for watching. Claudia Boleyn,
